case_name: Sahib Singh Mehra v. State of U.P.

facts.text: Sahib Singh Mehra published an article in his paper Kaliyug of Aligarh dated September 12, 1960 under the heading Ultra Chor Kotwal Ko Dante

anchor.surface_text: Sahib Singh Mehra, appellant in this appeal by special leave, published an article in his paper Kaliyug of Aligarh, dated September 12, 1960, under the heading Ultra Chor Kotwal Ko Dante which means that a thief reprimanded the kotwal, a police officer, though the right thing would be the other way.

facts.text: The article contained expressions about justice as helpless spectator of illicit bribe money from plaintiffs and defendants entering pockets of public prosecutors and assistant public prosecutors

anchor.surface_text: The article companytained the following expressions, as translated How the justice stands at a distance as a helpless spectator of the show as to the manner in which the illicit bribe money from plaintiffs and defendants enters into the pockets of public prosecutors and assistant public prosecutors and the extent to which it reaches and to which use it is put.

facts.text: Public Prosecutor and eleven Assistant Public Prosecutors at Aligarh requested Superintendent of Police for sanction to file complaint under s.500 IPC

anchor.surface_text: The Public Prosecutor and the eleven Assistant Public Prosecutors at Aligarh requested the Superintendent of Police for obtaining the sanction of the Government for filing a companyplaint by the District Government Counsel in the Court of the Sessions Judge under s. 500 I.P.C.

facts.text: Home Secretary U.P. Government wrote to Inspector General U.P. on March 1, 1961 conveying sanction under section 198B CrPC for filing complaint under s.500 IPC against Editor and Publisher of Kaliyug for article dated September 12, 1960 defamatory against Sri R.K. Sharma and other police prosecuting staff

anchor.surface_text: The Government was duly approached through proper channel and, ultimately, the Home Secretary, U.P. Government, wrote to the Inspector General, U.P. on March 1, 1961 I am directed to companyvey the sanction of the State Government under section 198B c  of the Code of Criminal Procedure to the filing of a companyplaint under section 500 Indian Penal Code in a Court of Sessions, against the Editor and Publisher of the Newspaper Kaliyug of District Aligarh which published a news item under the caption Ulta Chor Kotwal Ko Dante in its issue, dated September 12, 1960 companytaining defamatory remarks against the Assistant Public Prosecutor Sri R. K. Sharma of District Aligarh and other police prosecuting staff of the Government in respect of their companyduct in the discharge of public functions.

facts.text: Public Prosecutor of Aligarh filed complaint in Court of Session Aligarh praying for summoning accused and trial under s.500 IPC

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Public Prosecutor of Aligarh filed the companyplaint in the Court of Session, Aligarh, praying for the summoning of the accused and for his trial according to law for the offence under s. 500 I.P.C.

facts.text: Appellant admitted before Sessions Judge the publication of the impugned article, stated no evil intention, published for public good in general terms to bring to notice of Government

anchor.surface_text: The appellant admitted before the Sessions Judge the publi- cation of the impugned article and stated that he never had any evil intention. He further stated that he had published the news item for the good of the public and that he had published it in most general terms to bring bad things to the numberice of the Government and the authorities for the public good.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted appellant under s.500 IPC, held statements defamatory not protected by exceptions 3 and 9 to s.499 IPC, sentenced to simple imprisonment for six months and fine Rs.200

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge companyvicted him of the offence under s. 500 P.C. holding that the aforesaid statements in the article were defamatory and that the appellant was number protected by exceptions 3 and 9 to s. 499 I.P.C. He sentenced the appellant to simple imprisonment for six months and a fine of Rs. 200.

facts.text: Appeal against conviction dismissed by Allahabad High Court by judgment dated January 29, 1963 in Criminal Appeal No. 998 of 1962

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 47 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated January 29, 1963 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 998 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 47 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated January 29, 1963 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 998 of 1962.

facts.text: Appellant published something defamatory of R.K. Sharma in May 1960

anchor.surface_text: The appellant published sometime in May 1960 something which was defamatory of R. K. Sharma. R. K. Sharma filed a companyplaint about it in September 1960.

facts.text: R.K. Sharma filed complaint about earlier publication in September 1960

anchor.surface_text: The appellant published sometime in May 1960 something which was defamatory of R. K. Sharma. R. K. Sharma filed a companyplaint about it in September 1960.

facts.text: Impugned article referred to earlier publication about R.K. Sharma and news of him contemplating court action, editor welcomed to expose bribe money

Sharma was companytemplating taking action in a Court of law and then expressed that the Editor welcomed the news and would show how the bribe money reaches the Public Prosecutors, how it is utilised andhow justice sees all this show from a distance.

facts.text: Public Prosecutor complaint restricted to defamation of R.K. Sharma and other police prosecuting staff at Aligarh

anchor.surface_text: The Public Prosecutor, however, in his companyplaint, restricted it to the defamation of R. K. Sharma and other police prosecuting staff of the P. Government at Aligarh.

anchor.surface_text: Section 499 I.P.C. defines defamation and provides inter alia that whoever makes or publishes any imputation concerning any person intending to harm, or knowing or having reason to believe that such imputation will harm, the reputation of such person, is said, except in cases covered by the exceptions to the Section, to, defame that person.

concepts.interpretation: Includes imputation concerning a collection of persons if identifiable; impugned remarks per se defamatory of identifiable group of prosecutors.

anchor.surface_text: Section 198 Cr. P.C. provides inter alia that no Court shall take cognizance of an offence falling under Chapter XXI  which contains ss. 499 and 500 I.P.C.  except upon complaint made by some person aggrieved by such offence.

concepts.interpretation: Generally requires complaint by aggrieved person for defamation, but excepted by s.198B for public servants.

issues.text: whether the Government did grant the sanction or whether the granting of the sanction by the Government had been duly proved in the case

anchor.surface_text: What was urged in the petition for special leave was that one of the questions of law which arose in the case for consideration was whether the charge framed was the one for which sanction was granted or the requisite complaint was filed. This question is very much different from the question whether the Government did grant the sanction or whether the granting of the sanction by the Government had been duly proved in the case.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: , he deserves a deterrent sentence. We dismiss the appeal.

arguments.court_reasoning: No justification; press must take care, reckless comments to be avoided, deterrent sentence deserved

arguments.claim: Persons responsible for newspapers should take care; reckless comments avoided; deterrent sentence for ulterior motive

anchor.surface_text: We do not see any justification for reducing the sentence. The Press has great power... Reckless comments are to be avoided. When one is proved to have made defamatory comments with an ulterior motive... he deserves a deterrent sentence.

holdings.text: The sanction was specific to the defamation of R.K. Sharma and other prosecuting staff and there was nothing wrong in the form of the sanction.

anchor.surface_text: The sanction referred to above, in this case, and conveyed by the Home Secretary to the Inspector-General of Police, was a sanction for making a complaint under S. 500 P.C. against the appellant with respect to the article under the heading Ulta Chor Kotwal Ko Dante, in the issue of Kaliyug dated September 12, 1960, containing defamatory remarks against the Assistant Public Prosecutor, R. K. Sharma, of Aligarh, and other prosecuting staff of the Government in respect of their conduct in the discharge of public functions. The sanction was therefore with respect to defamation of two persons (i) R. K. Sharma, Assistant Public prosecutor, Aligarh and (ii) the other police prosecuting staff of Government of Uttar Pradesh, which would be the entire prosecuting staff in the State. There was thus nothing wrong in the form of the sanction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sanction explicitly references the article, R.K. Sharma, and other prosecuting staff, satisfying requirements of s.198B(3) CrPC.

holdings.text: Prosecuting staff at Aligarh constitutes an identifiable collection of persons under Explanation 2 to s.499 IPC and can be defamed.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecuting staff of Aligarh or, as a matter of fact, the prosecuting staff in the State of Uttar Pradesh, is certainly such an identifiable group or collection of persons. There is nothing indefinite about it. This group consists of all members of the prosecuting staff in the service of the Government of Uttar Pradesh. Within this general group of Public Prosecutors of U.P. there is again an identifiable group of prosecuting staff, consisting of Public Prosecutor and Assistant Public Prosecutors, at Aligarh.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explanation 2 explicitly covers imputations concerning a collection of persons if identifiable, distinguishing from indefinite community; Aligarh staff is specific and identifiable.

holdings.text: It is not essential for an offence under s.500 IPC that the person defamed be an individual; a collection of persons such as prosecuting staff can be defamed.

anchor.surface_text: The next question to determine is whether it is essential for the purpose of an offence under S. 500 I.P.C. that the person defamed must be an individual and that the prosecuting staff at Aligarh or of the State of Uttar Pradesh could not be said to be a person which could be defamed. Section 499 I.P.C. defines defamation... Explanation 2 provides that it may amount to defamation to make an imputation concerning a company or an association or collection of persons as such.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.499 and Expl 2 define defamation to include collections of identifiable persons, not limited to individuals.

holdings.text: The impugned remarks are per se defamatory of the group of public prosecutors and assistant public prosecutors at Aligarh.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Remarks impute bribe-taking and corruption, which lowers moral character and reputation in eyes of others.

holdings.text: The defamed group had reputation which could be harmed, as per presumption and evidence that they are not corrupt.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal presumption of good reputation applies unless rebutted; prosecutors testified to integrity, no contrary proof.

holdings.text: Appellant not protected by Exceptions 3 and 9 to s.499 IPC as no good faith or public good established.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No due care shown for good faith under Exc 3; tenor shows ulterior motive to deter litigation, not public good under Exc 9.

holdings.text: Appellant committed offence under s.500 IPC by defaming Public Prosecutor and Assistant Public Prosecutors at Aligarh; conviction upheld.
holdings.reasoning_summary: All elements of defamation satisfied against identifiable group; defenses fail; lower courts correct.

holdings.text: No justification to reduce sentence; deterrent sentence deserved for reckless defamatory comments by press with ulterior motive.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Press responsibility requires care; ulterior motive and recklessness warrant deterrence over leniency.

anchor.surface_text: We dismiss the appeal.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; conviction under s. 500 IPC and sentence of simple imprisonment for six months and fine of Rs. 200 upheld; no reduction in sentence

anchor.surface_text: The sanction referred to above, in this case, and conveyed by the Home Secretary to the Inspector-General of Police, was a sanction for making a complaint under S. 500 P.C. against the appellant with respect to the article under the heading Ulta Chor Kotwal Ko Dante, in the issue of Kaliyug dated September 12, 1960, containing defamatory remarks against the Assistant Public Prosecutor, R. K. Sharma, of Aligarh, and other prosecuting staff of the Government in respect of their conduct in the discharge of public functions. The sanction was therefore with respect to defamation of two persons (i) R. K. Sharma, Assistant Public prosecutor, Aligarh and (ii) the other police prosecuting staff of Government of Uttar Pradesh, which would be the entire prosecuting staff in the State. There was thus nothing wrong in the form of the sanction.
We dismiss the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecuting staff of Aligarh or, as a matter of fact, the prosecuting staff in the State of Uttar Pradesh, is certainly such an identifiable group or collection of persons. There is nothing indefinite about it. This group consists of all members of the prosecuting staff in the service of the Government of Uttar Pradesh. Within this general group of Public Prosecutors of U.P. there is again an identifiable group of prosecuting staff, consisting of Public Prosecutor and Assistant Public Prosecutors, at Aligarh.

anchor.surface_text: We dismiss the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The next question to determine is whether it is essential for the purpose of an offence under S. 500 I.P.C. that the person defamed must be an individual and that the prosecuting staff at Aligarh or of the State of Uttar Pradesh could not be said to be a person which could be defamed. Section 499 I.P.C. defines defamation... Explanation 2 provides that it may amount to defamation to make an imputation concerning a company or an association or collection of persons as such.
We dismiss the appeal.
